content: garden trellis by wendee shulsen hazel knits this flirty boho-chic scarf features a bobble stitch on front prominent and back subtle that resembles little rosebuds when knit in assigned pooling yarns the placement of the pattern stitch is mostly determined by the color pops in the yarn which creates that just one more row excitement materials yarn 1 skein hazel knits lively dk 275 yards sample color rose garden hook us 7 4 5mm wet blocking tools pins a surface to pin to tapestry needle gauge 16 stitches = 4 in double_crochet gauge is not critical however changes in gauge will affect yarn yardage and size garden trellis by wendee shulsen www hazelknits com - wendee@hazelknits com page 1 pattern notes abbreviations this scarf is worked from one side to the other turning after chain - chain each row after the chain and first two foundation row you double_crochet - double_crochet begin increasing every other row to create a tapered end sts - stitches and then eventually spreading out the increases in sets of rs - right side front side odd numbered row row for a gentle widening and then mirroring the ws - wrong side back side even numbered row decreases to create a long symmetrical scarf the dc5tog - bobble stitch increases/decreases always take place on the same edge single_crochet - single_crochet on the odd size row i find it s helpful to put a stitch marker on that side somewhere so that you can easily recognize if it s an increase/decrease row the yarn used in garden trellis is dyed with a long stretch of main color pale blue and a smaller contrasting burst of color green/berry in the pattern the pale blue will be referred to as mc and the bright color pop will be referred to as cc a bobble stitch is a textural stitch typically placed on the back side of the piece or wrong side as bobble construction creates a pop on the opposite side of the work bobbles are incorporated into your piece when you reach the cc starting with row 6 in this pattern you will place your bobble stitches on both sides of the pattern creating texture for reversible scarf because the cc of the yarn is free-form you may find sometimes your bobbles will be too close to a previous bobble or you may have a bobble too close to the edge of the work if this happens just double_crochet through the cc i did this several times in the sample as it looks great when close to a bobble or on the end always be sure you have at least two available stitches before the edge when placing a bobble i usually started my bobble right as close to when the berry color starts in the cc i did regular double_crochet stitch where the color was green for a leafy effect i opted for a single turning chain to allow for bobbles to be close to the edge
